Posts.Content: sending you love and positive thoughts, it probably seems impossible at the moment but if you can think about things that make you smile it will get the good hormones working which will help you recover bit by bit from the hurt. Anne xx
Posts.Title: So bloody angry

Posts.Content: Hi Andy, Welcome to the group, and at the same time sorry you've had to join us. It would probably be worth calling a MacMillan nurse and/or asking for more information from your mum's clinical team. I only know women who have had just chemo, or chemo and radiotherapy, so not a great help. If the cancer is HER2 positive (HER2 is a hormone cancer uses to grow) Herceptin is also offered, and if it's oestrogen positive, hormone suppressants are also offered later in the treatment. Good luck to you both.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or Chemo??

Posts.Content: I waited 8 weeks but could probably have driven fine from 5 weeks. Anne x
Posts.Title: Driving after LD flap recpnstruction

Posts.Content: Well done Bon! I do mine tomorrow at 2pm :)
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: yesterday I went back to bed 'cos I didn't have enough energy to stay up. Today I walked two miles and feel normal again (day 6 after first chemo) I was quite worried yesterday and am sooo happy today xxx
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: it's lovely to feel normal again isn't it xxx
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: wonderful news Bon! Keep on going. Anne xx
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: Well done Bon! I do mine tomorrow at 2pm :)
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: that's great to hear Kathnorm, hopefully people will pick up this thread and ask for them everywhere :) xx
Posts.Title: Finally getting my portacath fitted yeah xxx

Posts.Content: So pleased it's being fitted grannylara. The oncology nurse practically insisted I had one, but I had the luck to have taken out health insurance just in time, the cost was around £700, but  a PICC line is equally good for the veins I understand and wouldn't cost so much. If everyone knew about portacath/picc lines and asked for one to be fitted maybe the nhs would fit them, it's got to be worth it.
Posts.Title: Finally getting my portacath fitted yeah xxx

Posts.Content: I have just started using Jane Plant's recipe book following diagnosis last month. It isn't an enormous adjustment because I was already dairy intolerant and ate white meat and fish only. the biggest challenges are buying food not packaged in plastic, no microwaving, and no plastic containers or water filter jug....Anne x.
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: Hi, I have a portacath which sits just under the collar bone underneath the skin, it's put in under sedation in theatre but well worth it as the chemo goes in to a much larger vein than the delicate arm veins. It's also used to take blood. Definitely recommend it. Anne xx
Posts.Title: About to start chemo. Implantable port/central line?

Posts.Content: I would support the portacath option. The oncology nurse I saw for the first session says she persuades everyone she can to have this option even though it means going into theatre for the procedure because the veins in our arms are so delicate, not everyone wants it of course. If you would be happy to have one put in it could be worth asking for it. I hope it all works out. love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Help ..... my veins are giving up !

Posts.Content: Hi Denise, Congratulations on taking the next step!   My hair is about an inch long, a bit sparse still, and very grey on top, I coloured it recently and it went rather bright orange - I've bought a darker shade for the next attempt :) I'm quite torn about giving up the wig, it looks so much nicer than my own hair, but I am a bit concerned about the summer and getting too hot under the wig with growing hair.... Anne x
Posts.Title: Took the plunge and went to hairdressers today ...

Posts.Content: I've just completed 4 x3 EC chemo, moving on to paclitaxol 12 x 1 soon, plus Herceptin....the question is about my face! The skin around my chin and lips seem, to me, to have gained a lot of lines as though it's really thinned out...am I going mad or is this common? My onc says she hasn't noticed anything, but then she didn't know me before. My family haven't mentioned it (nor have I) and I'm assuming they don't want to hurt my feelings (and I don't want to sound sorry for myself.) In the end it's a small price to pay I know...I have started to consider plastic surgery though...Anne xxx
Posts.Title: What chemo does to facial skin

Posts.Content: Thanks Katee and Liz, it's good to know I'm not imagining things, and I'll hand on to see if it improves, ten years older is about right I think at the moment. Anne xx
Posts.Title: What chemo does to facial skin

Posts.Content: Hi Chloecat, I found your thread very recently and hats off to you. I know two women who also are taking the non surgery / chemo route, diet is the main area they focus on, growing wheatgrass and other 'sprouts' at home for juicing. I'm doing a mix of diet, surgery and chemo as lots of us do, and also working on keeping endorphins high and adrenalin and cortisol low - gut feel tells me stress and anger played a big role in my cancer. A useful book for me is The Endorphin Effect by William Bloom. It would be fantastic to find an option that makes chemo redundant. Thank you for posting such useful information. Anne
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I have my first chemo (EC) at one o' clock, feeling ok apart from worry about the short and long term side effects. I really don't want to cry when I'm there so positive vibes from you guys would be great. Thanks All. Anne xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Thank you JD :)
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, Your support makes a big difference! Nurse was lovely. I've got various meds to take home with recommended timings to avoid insomnia. it wasn't scary so no tears, and no immediate side effects ( the nurse warned me I mght have burning bottom as the cyclophosphamide went in). I'll believe paying for more advice soon I'm sure. Anne xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: please excuse typos - I was using my phone! Home now and still ok, pink urine though! Thanks again for all the support xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Hi KitKaty, day 2 and all is well thank you :) I have four different anti emetics, including Emend, and they're doing the trick. I discovered this morning I'd taken half the dose for two of them yesterday and felt vague nausea this morning - sorted out today. You're right on food cravings, I was desperate for a fried egg sandwich last night and had two! Thanks again for asking.
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: your hubbie is clearly a star, if he ever sets up a hotel let me know I'm booking in :)
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Thank you Susie and you're right it wasn't so bad at all. Yes, the nurse did say tonight or tomorrow, I think I have three types of anti sickness tablets to take so hopefully will avoid being ill. I will go and get a drink now :) xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: you're so right, fried eggs - twice a year normally not twice a day! Day four and feel good, just a little tired but working from home so can't be bad xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Hi CLK888, I hope you're beginning to feel better. Day 5, I found to be a very tired day and I did go back to bed, on day 6 (today) my energy has returned. I was given four different anti emetics, reducing gradually to one type from day 5, plus an anti indigestion tablet, and the ok to take Gaviscon, and they seem to have worked well. If the full list would be useful let me know and I'll try to spell them right! I don't know if it's helped but I have dropped all dairy, most meat, and sugar from my diet. A massage would be lovely, or reflexology, but I'm not sure if a therapist would treat us at this stage. You can always do reflexology yourself of course - there is science to it but a good massage all over the feet always feels good, and squeeze each toe at the tip:) It would be lovely if the next treatment were easier but will have to wait and see. Love and hugs. Anne xx
Posts.Title: First Chemo Today - Moral Support Request

Posts.Content: Thanks very much Claire and Liz, very useful points and having read so much on here about side effects I was beginning to think it might be unrealistic to get there by train on my own. The Royal Marsden oncologist provided lots of information and confirmed the recommendations made by my local hospital oncologist which was reassuring and means I will stay local which is a relief, it was quite a trek up and there back today. Thanks again. Anne
Posts.Title: Travel Time To Chemo

Posts.Content: Good Morning Everyone, I have an appointment with an oncologist at the Royal Marsden this morning for a second opinion. Please would you comment on realistic travel time for chemo? If I transfer to the Marsden it will take an hour and 15 minutes each way, if possible I'd prefer to take the train and tube but could arrange to be driven. The alternative is a 15 minute drive. If the Marsden approach is much better I'll do it, but would really appreciate your comments on this. Many Thanks Anne
Posts.Title: Travel Time To Chemo

Posts.Content: The posts here helped me decide to request a referral to the Royal Marsden - thank you. Anne x
Posts.Title: recent diagnosis of breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Claire, It sounds exhausting for you, and it doesn't help when you feel bad for keeping Julie awake as well. I have no experience of radiotherapy so can't share any useful thoughts on that front I wondered if it's possible to set up alternative sleeping quarters for awake nights, or quietly leave the room? It might be worth asking your medical team if they can help too, although most of us don't want to add to our medicine intake... Also talk to Julie, she might be getting enough sleep, or you could explain that you cope better if she does sleep. She might have some better ideas than these :) Sending you love and hugs. Anne x
Posts.Title: always tired

Posts.Content: Hi Gill, I was also diagnosed in September, I had a mastectomy and rebuild also on 6th October and started the chemo today. I have 3 x 15 year olds and a nearly 18 year old, so far they're concerned, caring and well balanced but I have been very well of course so I'm a bit worried out looking unwell to them. They have A Levels/GCSEs this year so quite tough on them but school are keeping an eye out for them. My son has type 1 so I'm aware of the injections you have to deal with too. Your family sound wonderful, as do you! It's tough to keep positive all the time but you're clearly giving it a go! One idea I was given was to focus on how I feel (happy etc.) and then think about what's going on around me and in my life, rather than let what's going on around me etc. decide how I feel - subtle but can help, I manage it about 10% of the time so far. For chemo etc. I have a portacath which is inserted into the upper left or right chest under the skin when you're sedated.All fluids are given via this and all bloods taken from there too. It does involve a single insertion of a needle into the portacath at each visit which is like an injection but might mean the minimum number of needles to deal with for you. The Hba1c blood could also be taken from the portacath if you wish. The PICC line is probably similar but I know less about it. I get brain freeze from ice lollies so declined the cold cap - wimp hey:) I hope that ramble is a bit useful. Love Anne xx
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Grade 3 Ductal Carcinoma non Lymph

Posts.Content: PS Gill, have you looked into getting a pump for the insulin to reduce injections (apologies everyone a bit off topic but relevant I hope for Gill)
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Grade 3 Ductal Carcinoma non Lymph

Posts.Content: just following up on the lymphoedema part of the thread. At the Royal Marsden they are doing a new operation using microsurgery to connect the lymph up with the veins to relieve lymphoedema. I don't know if it's just for arm lymphoedema but could be worth asking xxx
Posts.Title: I'm Feeling Scared

Posts.Content: my breast care nurse referred me for counselling with the Wessex Cancer Trust, the first session happened within a week, there is no charge and they offer up to six sessions. This is in Hampshire if you're here, if not it could be worth asking what's available where you are. Lots of love xxx
Posts.Title: feeling sad and angry after having had breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi All, lots of people seem to have FEC, has anyone had just EC? I have 4 sessions to come followed by weekly taxol (Paclitaxel) and herceptin. Any comments on side effects, and how to avoid, them very welcome :) xxxx
Posts.Title: Anyone had EC chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thanks very much for the ideas - lots of water and advance tablets for constipation especially, I had horrible constipation after the mastectomy/reconstruction and really don't want to go there again. I'm having a portcath fitted tomorrow so I'll ask about if I can have advance tablets. I'm procrastinating on the chemo, thinking of all sorts of reasons not to start it now, one oncologist said it would be ok to wait until 10 weeks after the op but I really should bite the bullet. Thanks again for the support, love this forum. Anne xx
Posts.Title: Anyone had EC chemotherapy
